Title.evidence: Suture UMbilical MEsh Repair (SUMMER) Trial: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: A randomised, controlled, parallel-group, double-blind, multicentre trial was conducted across six Swedish surgical units.

Participants.evidence: Adults with primary elective UHs ≤2 cm were eligible.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised 1:1 to either 4 × 4 cm macroporous lightweight onlay mesh repair or conventional suture repair.

Objective.evidence: This trial evaluates surgical-site occurrences (SSOs) in suture versus mesh repair for umbilical hernias (UHs) ≤2 cm.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome is recurrence at 3 years, with secondary outcomes including SSOs and pain intensity at 30 days.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Intraoperative web-based randomisation ensured allocation concealment.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding included patients and outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: From February 2020 to January 2024, 290 participants were randomised: 146 to suture repair and 144 to mesh repair.

Number_Analysed.evidence: After exclusions, 144 suture and 135 mesh participants were analysed.

Result_Outcome.evidence: SSOs (Clavien–Dindo grade ≥I) affected 32 mesh (23.7%) and 26 suture (18.1%) participants, with no significant increase for mesh (OR 1.39, 95% CI 0.78 to 2.51).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were similar between groups, with no severe complications reported.
